_source.complaint_what_happened: Recently, I noticed that I am starting to receive collection mails from banks. I called and asked what is going on, and I was told that there are several accounts opened last year with my information. I told them that I have never submitted any types of application to their companies. They asked my address, email address, phone number, social security number, date of birth, and name. Surprisingly, Some of cards mailed to my business addresses, and some of them were mailed to my home in the state of XXXX. However, I never received those cards before. I travel from state to state for my business, so I couldn't check my mailbox everyday. Maybe someone got access to my mailbox and took the card after they applied for it. But that does not mean that I am responsible for these cards ' payments and outstanding balances. I already informed what is happening, and I also submitted FTC report to XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX. It has been about few months now, but I see no changes in my credit report. As a business owner, I was planning to expand my business in other state this year, but with current status of my credit report -- full of credit cards that I have never applied for -- I can't even get any commercial loan. I am not sure what my credit bureaus are doing, but although I submitted all documents they requested ( copy of my driver 's license, social security card, utility bill, and FTC report ), I see no efforts of my credit bureaus. Everything remains same, no updates, nothing. My most recent dispute case closed with the result of " these are correct information '' did not explain anything. I don't know what kind of document or verification document they received from credit card companies, but I never got a chance to look at it. I asked if they can send me a copy of what they have, but they rejected my request and said : unfortunately we can not provide you any documents from creditors due to privacy information. Well, they started dispute case because they were able to verify that I am the one who submitted these disputes. Then how come they can not provide me any proof for privacy issue? Representatives said that they sent out a mail explaining everything, but the result letter did not explain anything. I just saw a letter saying their investigation concluded as " they are all correct information. '' BUT HOW DO THEY EXPECT ME TO AGREE WITH INVESTIGATION RESULT WITHOUT ANY PROOF? I don't even know how identity thief obtained my information, what kind of information was submitted. I can't understand or agree with their process of investigation. As a result, they made me come to you ( CFPB ) and to ask for help with my current status. I never applied for any credit cards with these companies.

They told me to use a different service I tried to use XXXX and they declined my XXXX transfer and they are just making it absolutely impossible for me to use my standard form of payment to pay my rent which is now a week late. I am devastated that no one can help me. Theres absolutely no one. That knows what theyre doing there and they can help. I am XXXX XXXX XXXX and the nearest bank to me since I moved is XXXX miles away, and they have actually told me at Td Bank to go into a local branch and when I tell them how far away it is, they say OK well go into the local branch these people do not care at all and habe offered no help whatsoever

_source.complaint_what_happened:
My partner and I opened a Bank of America joint Adv SafeBalance account ( # XXXX ) online on XX/XX/2024. I was able to authenticate and access the account online ; however, my partner XXXX XXXX XXXX ) was unable to for unknown reasons. When trying through both the app and the website, neither would acknowledge his social security number as associated with the account. We contacted customer service via phone and were told to wait a few days and/or until the debit cards arrived for him to try again on creating his profile online. On the afternoon of XX/XX/2024, I also lost access to the account online and was told I had to go into a financial center to regain access to the account. No explanation was provided at that time. 

On XX/XX/2024, we visited the XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, NC ) to regain access to the account. Upon speaking with XXXX bankers, we learned that the account had been frozen/closed due to suspected debit card fraud or apparently failure to properly authenticate the owners. I can only assume this was somehow due to my partner 's information not being associated with the account despite him being a co-applicant or some other operational error on BoA 's side. In any case, we opened another joint account at the financial center which would have been the end of the issue. However, prior to losing access to the original account, I had transferred into it {$250.00} and that is where the problem continues today. 

While at the XXXX XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX, the banker stated that he had initiated a process whereby the frozen account would be closed and a check would be mailed to me within XXXX business days. As of today XX/XX/XXXX, after having visited that same financial center again, the {$250.00} remains in the frozen/closed account. I told the manager of that branch today that I really needed access to those {$250.00} and requested that I be given a {$250.00} cashiers check, and that BoA could just keep the funds in the closed account. The manager essentially told me there was nothing he could do and that I would just have to wait for the check to be sent to me. Neither he, the banker I worked with directly, nor the representatives they had on the phone today could tell me when I would be getting the check, even though it's already been nearly XXXX weeks since first trying to resolve this issue. 

This has been an incredibly frustrating experience, and I left that XXXX XXXX  today feeling like Bank of America did not care about me as a customer needing access to their funds or really even as a person taking time out of their day and visiting a branch ( for the second time ) trying to resolve a problem that was no fault of their own. I requested that the second account be closed, but I really would just like my {$250.00} so that I can move on.

_source.complaint_what_happened: I was a victim of a rental property scam in XXXX, NC. I submitted an application through XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX company and was contacted the next morning by an individual by the name of XXXX XXXX stating that the property I applied for was taken and he had another property available. He provided me with the code to the XXXX  I agreed to wanting the house he sent me an invoice for the security deposit of XXXX which was to be sent via XXXX. This invoice was on XXXX letterhead. After receiving and signing a lease I sent another {$1500.00} for the first months rent. After contacting XXXX and being made aware it was a scam I reached out to PNC to dispute the charges on XX/XX/2023 and I also opened a police report with the XXXX, NC Police Department. XX/XX/2023 PNC sent communication letting me know that my request had been denied.

I am writing to express my disappointment with the inaccurate credit reporting done by Barclays Bank. This reporting has severely damaged my financial situation. On XX/XX/2023, I noticed a new account on my credit report that I did not open. I immediately sent a notice to Barclays Bank in Delaware, requesting them to validate the debt and remove it from my credit report. I sent this notice via certified mail with tracking number XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. Despite my notice, Barclays Bank has not responded or taken any action to remove the debt from my credit report. As a result, my credit score and report has been damaged, making it difficult for me to obtain credit, which I need to purchase a home. I am requesting that Barclays Bank of Delaware immediately remove the disputed debt from my credit report. I am also requesting that they provide me with a copy of the validation letter that they sent to the credit bureaus. If Barclays Bank does not take action to resolve this matter, I will be forced to take further action, including filing a lawsuit.

_source.complaint_what_happened:
Subject : Urgent Request for Documentation and Action Regarding Unauthorized Inquiry and Security Interest Dear TD Auto Finance, I am writing to address a concerning matter regarding an inquiry reported by TD Auto Finance, which lacks permissible purpose and, as such, constitutes potential identity fraud. Per my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically Sections 604 and 605B, I am requesting immediate action to rectify this situation. 

Firstly, I require documentation proving that I provided express written consent for TD Auto Finance to report the inquiry in question. As there is no evidence of such consent or a court order, I must assert that this inquiry lacks legitimacy and is thus subject to removal.

Per the FCRA Section 605B, a consumer reporting agency must block the reporting of any information resulting from alleged identity theft when identified by the consumer. Therefore, I am formally notifying TD Auto Finance to remove this inquiry from my file within four business days. 

Furthermore, it has come to my attention that XXXX XXXX neglected to inform me of my right to rescission, as outlined in the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ), specifically Regulation Z ( 12 CFR 1026.23 ). This allows me to revoke any rights waived, particularly those related to the security interest. I am requesting the CUSIP number associated with the security interest provided to TD Auto Finance. Failure to provide this information will leave me with no alternative but to initiate a level 3 audit on my account.

I expect prompt compliance with these requests to avoid further escalation of this matter. Failure to do so will be regarded as willful noncompliance and may result in legal action.

Please provide confirmation of receipt of this letter and a timeline for resolution of these issues.
_source.sub_issue: Credit inquiries on your report that you don't recognize

_source.complaint_what_happened:
I have a HELOC with TD Bank that I'm looking to have paid off and closed. 

I requested information from the bank for how to get a Verification of Mortgage from TD. 

I received a response bank from their digital team with instructions. 

I followed the instructions provided and the loan processor sent in the verification request. 

The f

irst 3 requests did not get a response. The 4 request I was told, could not
be processed due to not having a specific verification form filled out. Even though the instructions provide to me by TD Bank originally stated I just needed to send them a letter. I spoke to a representative who repeatedly told me that a letter is not acceptable and that I need to have the specific form signed and resend it in to her attention and she would call if there were any problems. 

I called 2 days later after not receiving a call from the representative asking for the status of the document and was told that since my signature on the request does not match the original document from 2018 they can not process my request. 

I explained that my signature has changed since then and what can I do to get this corrected, they stated that without a signature match there was nothing I can do. 

I understand that my signature is not the same as 2018, but I still need my verification of mortgage request completed somehow. TD Bank as a company is unable to tell me what I can do to get this requested resolved. They are giving me no other option to get me verified so that this VOM can be sent. 

I have been verified by TD over the phone, through their VoicePrint service and the secure text codes, so they are able to verify who I am. 

After speaking with numerous representatives it appears that no one is able to assist. I have been told we can " try this or try that '' but no one can tell me what needs to be done to get this processed. I've received different answers from most of the representatives I spoke to. 

The bank is causing me financial strain as I am trying to make these payments each month and the payments have increased significantly due to interest rates. 

I feel as if TD is intentionally delaying the payoff and closing of my loan so they can continue to collect the high interest payments from me and keep this loan on the books. 

As a top US Bank TD should have clear and simple instructions to provide to a customer when handling their requests.
_source.sub_product: Home equity loan or line of credit (HELOC)
_source.sub_issue: Trying to communicate with the company to fix an issue while managing or servicing your loan

_source.complaint_what_happened:
On XXXX XXXX XXXX the IRS accepted the 1099-C for the cancellation of debt owed to Busey Bank . A copy of the 1099-C was received by me from the IRS advising me that the debt has been discharged ( cancelled or forgiven ) and Busey Bank is still attempting to collect on the charged off loan. Additionally, payment was sent in full to the indenture trustee XXXX XXXX with XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. Though I have not yet heard back from her, according to the UCC, 3-603. TENDER OF PAYMENT.

( a ) If tender of payment of an obligation to pay an instrument is made to a person entitled to enforce the instrument, the effect of tender is governed by principles of law applicable to tender of payment under a simple contract.

( b ) If tender of payment of an obligation to pay an instrument is made to a person entitled to enforce the instrument and the tender is refused, there is discharge, to the extent of the amount of the tender, of the obligation of an indorser or accommodation party having a right of recourse with respect to the obligation to which the tender relates.

Additionally, federal law says that it's illegal to report transaction history.

NOTICE ANY HOLDER OF THIS CONSUMER CREDIT CONTRACT IS SUBJECT TO ALL CLAIMS AND DEFENSES WHICH THE DEBTOR COULD ASSERT AGAINST THE SELLER OF GOODS OR SERVICES OBTAINED PURSUANT HERETO OR WITH THE PROCEEDS HEREOF. RECOVERY HEREUNDER BY THE DEBTOR SHALL NOT EXCEED AMOUNTS PAID BY THE DEBTOR HEREUNDER. Per 16 CFR 433.2.

Also, pursuant to 16 CFR 433.1 I was supposed to receive a purchase money loan by law, but instead Busey Bank provided me with a consumer loan.

d ) Purchase money loan. A cash advance which is received by a consumer in return for a Finance Charge within the meaning of the Truth in Lending Act and Regulation Z, which is applied, in whole or substantial part, to a purchase of goods or services from a seller who ( 1 ) refers consumers to the creditor or ( 2 ) is affiliated with the creditor by common control, contract, or business arrangement.

Finally, pursuant to federal law a contract is only valid between a finance company and a seller that's in the ordinary course of business. So the initial contract that I signed with Busey Bank is void ab initio.

_source.complaint_what_happened:
Legislation should prohibit Discover Student Loans and their representatives, XXXX XXXX XXXX, from violating the rights and livelihood of individuals who turn to them for financial assistance with genuine intentions. 

Over the past decade, my family has faced financial challenges trying to meet the sizable monthly payments on two student loans. My daughter and son are the borrowers, and my husband and I are the cosigners. We're committed to fulfilling our financial obligations, but Discover has made this unattainable. We have lodged two complaints with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, reached out to relevant District Attorney 's offices, and directly contacted Discover 's leadership. Throughout this period, we've personally encountered tactics from Discover Student Loans that we view as infringing on our rights and indicative of predatory lending practices. Around two years ago, we had no choice but to default on these unmanageable loans. This decision was not made lightly, as we knew it would further damage our already compromised credit scores and hinder our ability to accumulate assets. Despite our plight, Discover showed no willingness to negotiate or take steps to ameliorate the situation. 

In XX/XX/XXXX, Discover filed civil suits against us, initiating another phase in our contentious financial struggle. We enlisted the help of a student loan attorney because XXXX XXXX XXXX, acting on behalf of Discover, refused to negotiate with us and demanded the full balance either upfront or in five-year installments. Our attorney managed to secure a reduced repayment rate of {$2400.00} per month for the next five years for both loans. Discover stipulated that missing even one payment would nullify the settlement agreement. Additionally, since Discover will consider the loans unsettled until the last cent is paid, both the students ' and cosigners ' credit scores will be negatively impacted until the final payment is made in five years, effectively holding our credit hostage over that duration of time. This severely limits our ability to make any credit-based transactions like buying a car or home, or even renting, while Discover continues to collect {$2400.00} monthly from us for the next five years. 

To complicate matters, the timeline for finalizing this settlement was unnecessarily tight. When the proposal was finally on the table on XX/XX/XXXX, we were informed that the first payment had to be wired before the month 's end ; otherwise, the deal would be off. Despite this tight deadline, there were multiple inaccuracies in the details they provided, such as wrong account numbers and addresses, misrepresentation to the District Court, inaccurate paperwork, etc., which we had to scramble to correct. Inaccuracies on DiscoverXXXX  part included : After making the initial mandated payment before the tight deadline, we discovered Discover/XXXX had omitted an entire account from the agreement. This missing information was sent later via regular mail, contrary to the expedited faxing they used for the rest of the account details. The omitted account was subsequently included in the settlement, which raised the agreed-upon amount by nearly {$4000.00} and increased our monthly payments by {$64.00}. Despite this oversight on their part, there were no apologies or accommodations made, although they held us strictly accountable to the original agreement payment deadline. 
We continuously received notifications from the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX in North Carolina regarding our selection for random arbitration. We reached out to XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, notifying her of our ongoing settlement agreements, which essentially serve the purpose of arbitration. This correspondence also included our attorney and XXXX attorneys. However, XXXX XXXX stated she needed verification from the plaintiff 's attorneys. Despite having communicated our settlement agreement, we were still provided with an arbitration date. Consequently, our attorney requested XXXX to update the courts. Yet, we were surprised when we received another notification of impending arbitration for a second case. I promptly communicated with XXXX XXXX, referencing all XXXX case files that had been settled. She acknowledged being aware of the settlement for the first case during the arbitration hearing that occurred on XXXX XXXX. It's perplexing that the court proceeded with arbitration for an already settled case. It's worth noting that we hadn't even provided the necessary documents, which were due two weeks prior to the arbitration date. Surprisingly, no one followed up on these missing documents. It raises questions about whether this arbitration was merely a procedural formality to ensure certain individuals received compensation. It seems like a misuse of taxpayers ' funds and a dubious system where individuals might be compensated without rendering actual services. Will this same situation arise for the other three Discover cases that we've already settled? 
On XX/XX/XXXX, our lawyer updated me about a conversation he had with XXXX the day before. They apparently did not receive our daughters payment made in XXXX. It's noteworthy that this is the same account for which they had given the wrong account number and still proceeded with an arbitration hearing. When we got the written agreement through mail for notarization back in XXXX, our attorney had immediately informed XXXX about the error in our daughters account number. At that time, they assured him they would ensure the funds were directed to the right account. However, they now claim not to have received the payment. It's important to note that both childrens payments for XXXX were sent together, via BoA wire, as a single transaction to expedite the process and avoid any penalties. The total amount included the due amounts for both accounts, clearly specifying both account numbers. From XXXX onward, we've made individual payments for each account. On XX/XX/XXXX, our lawyer found himself reiterating the same information to XXXX that he had shared back in XXXX. 
During the conversation our lawyer had with XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX mentioned that while they had received the notarized settlement copies for the children, they hadn't received them for the cosigners. However, the documents provided to us were specifically set up for notarization for our children only, not for the cosigners ( an example of this is available for reference ). A XXXX XXXX will only notarize a document for the individuals explicitly named on that document. XXXX suggested we use the same documents they initially sent. I advised our attorney to ask XXXX to provide us with the appropriate documents so that both my husband and I can duly get them notarized. 

These errors occurred as DiscoverXXXX maintained their demand for a turnaround of less than one week for the first payment. The entire process has been marked by errors and omissions, but also penalties, consistent with our past decade-long experience with Discover. Nonetheless, they continue to wield disproportionate power over our lives, unapologetically impairing our financial well-being and hindering our progress. Holding our credit profile XXXX for 5 years while they received {$2400.00} per month should be illegal. 

I know that Discover Bank has received attention from the CFPB ( Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ). I know that politicians such as XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, and XXXX XXXX are also spearheading legislation to stop predatory student loan lenders. XXXX XXXX created a bill called The CFPB Student Loan Integrity & Transparency Act of XXXX, which " would strengthen the oversight abilities of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau 's ( CFPB ) student loan ombudsman, the top federal official responsible for defending the interests of student borrowers struggling to repay their loans. '' " This officials oversight capabilities were undermined when CFPB Acting XXXX XXXX XXXX closed the only federal office solely dedicated to protecting student loan borrowers : the Office of Students and Younger Consumers. '' I know the CFPB also filed a lawsuit against a company with the names " College Financial Advisory '' and " Student Financial Resource Center '' for " conducting a nationwide operation that deceived students and their families into paying a fee in exchange for an illusory student financial aid program. '' Data shows that Student debt negatively impacts the economy and continues to Reinforce the XXXX wealth gap. '' Regardless of the incomes they make after graduation, XXXX households carry more student debt, which pushes down their creditworthiness. Unsurprisingly, then, XXXX people with a college degree have lower homeownership rates than white high school dropouts. '' " There is also a XXXX disparity in student borrowing that many experts say is problematic and the result of decades of systemic discrimination. '' ( XXXX on XXXX XXXX ). Then there are politicians such as XXXX XXXX who plan to put college legislation in place that will prohibit spending on diversity, equity, and inclusion ( DEI ) initiatives to make the atmosphere unpalatable to minorities and serve as another deterrent to the progression of marginalized people. 

While most of the impact of predatory lending lands on POCs ( People of XXXX ), all students who enter this system are preyed upon. Our family has over 10 years worth of experience with Discovers cruelty and unethical behavior. 

While regulatory scrutiny and fines from the CFPB have cast a spotlight on some of Discover Bank 's questionable practices ( as well as those of other lenders deemed predatory ), pinpointing the exact elements of their lending process that are illegal can be difficult. This is because their approach is often indirect and subtle, deliberately designed to maximize loan amounts at the expense of borrowers ' rights. While many individual aspects of their operations might not be explicitly illegal, their collective behavior can facilitate outcomes that are. 

Discover 's tactics often seem calibrated to set students and their cosigners up for failure from the outset. For instance, their use of forbearance and hardship programs often lacks full disclosure regarding how these options will affect monthly payments and overall loan amounts, luring borrowers into a false sense of relief. Instead of offering extended loan term programs that would lower monthly payments while increasing the loan term, they opt for forbearancewhich more quickly inflates the overall loan amount. They have also been implicated in a class-action lawsuit related to DACA, alleging discrimination in mortgage and student loans. 

In our personal experience, Discover had to correct inaccurately high interest rates and statement amounts for both of our children, adjustments that were made only after being flagged by the CFPB. Yet, these are not isolated incidents ; they represent broader systemic issues affecting a wide swath of borrowers, particularly those who are marginalized. The compounded effect is the widespread destruction of creditworthiness and a vicious cycle of financial disempowerment. 

While the CFPB has begun to address these problems, much remains to be done, especially considering the prevalence of predatory practices beyond just Discover. This is just the tip of the iceberg, but it's encouraging to know that regulatory agencies are watching closely. 

When a borrower opts for student loan forbearance, the aim is to temporarily suspend monthly payments. The terms may vary based on the lender and the loan type, and it's often the case that interest continues to accumulate during this period. The purpose of forbearance is to offer a short-term financial respite for borrowers going through economic difficulties. 

When our children sought more manageable monthly payments, Discover was quick to suggest forbearance, fully aware that this would result in higher monthly payments down the line, effectively trapping our children in a financial downward spiral while increasing Discover 's own profits. During my son 's final year of college, when he still had XXXX credit hours remaining, Discover insisted that he begin repaying his student loan. Despite his efforts to maintain interest-free deferment until he completed his education, Discover pushed for forbearance. We all fought strenuously to reverse this decision. 

Discover didn't just encourage our children to opt for forbearance and their Hardship Assistance Program when they had a late monthly payment ; they did so when our children merely expressed difficulty with the existing payments. Because Discover fixed the loan term at 10 years, the deferred payments and interest accrued during the forbearance and hardship periods were later added to the principal. This inflated the monthly payments since the loan term remained unchanged. For both of my children, these strategies, combined with high interest rates, would have substantially inflated the loan amount compared to what was originally disbursed. 

Our Experience with Discover Student Loans : Discover, aware of the typical salary a graduate can expect in relation to the loan amount, commits students to a 10-year loan term and requires a cosigner. 
Both the student and the cosigner undergo credit assessments for the loan, and we are informed that the interest rate range will be between 6.00 % and 9.00 %. Despite the cosigner having a high credit score in the upper 700s, the student is assigned an interest rate of 8.99 %. When questioned about the high rate and why the cosigner 's strong credit score wasn't considered, we are told that the student is the main borrower, not the cosigner. According to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, adding a cosigner with a strong credit score can substantially lower the interest ratepotentially by XXXX  percentage points or more. For example, a borrower with a credit score of XXXX could expect an interest rate between XXXX %, but adding a cosigner with a score of XXXX could reduce that rate to between XXXX %, resulting in significant savings. However, in our case, the student was given the maximum interest rate available at the time. ( This should be considered unethical, especially given the contradictory information provided later when the loan was due about the cosigner 's role as a " co-borrower. " ). 
Right after the student graduates, Discover reaches out to the cosigner for repayment, even before any payments are overdue. This approach raises questions about whether Discover had already anticipated that the student would fail to make payments. When queried about contacting the cosigner first, Discover labels us as " co-borrowers. '' Ironically, we weren't considered co-borrowers during the loan assessment, which would have potentially lowered the interest rate, but we suddenly became co-borrowers when it was repayment timedespite our strong credit scores having no impact on the initial rate. 
The student receives a staggering monthly bill of {$1200.00}, which is hard to manage on a $ XXXX salary. Discover suggests forbearance or hardship programs as a temporary fix. The representative glosses over important financial implications of forbearance, leading the student to opt for it without fully understanding its long-term impact. Six months later, the student is shocked to find out that monthly payments have increased, yet is advised to enter another round of forbearance or the Hardship Assistance Program, thereby exacerbating the situation. 
The downward financial spiral starts almost immediately, as each forbearance period renders the loan increasingly unmanageable for both the student and cosigner. Their credit scores also suffer due to late or missed payments. 
Attempts to secure a XXXX consolidation loan through Discover failed because of low credit scoreswhich have been damaged by the student loansas well as the high total amount owed in relation to income, further worsened by repeated forbearance periods. 
Efforts to consolidate the student loans with other lenders also hit a wall due to poor credit and high loan-to-income ratios, which have been worsened by the initial loans and the forbearance cycles. 
Both the students ' and cosigners ' prospects for stable employment and financial growth are compromised, as they struggle to balance loan repayment, daily living expenses, and retirement planning, all of which have been negatively impacted by Discover 's questionable practices. 
As loan payments fall further behind, both students and cosigners experience harassment, misinformation, credit reporting errors, and other forms of mistreatment, violating their right to fair and dignified treatment. 

Discover seems to understand the majority of students turning to them for loans are marginalized or underprivileged. Even when the loan was not in default, we were subjected to relentless harassment. Discover even unethically suggested that my children deliberately miss payments to exhibit financial hardship, employing strong-arm tactics such as bullying, credit damage, and falsehoods to extract money that arguably shouldn't have been due in the first place. 

Though attributing high interest rates and dismissing cosigner credit scores might be within legal bounds, it doesn't make it ethically sound. This, coupled with the dubious forbearance and hardship program policies, sketches out a blueprint of predatory lending that's genuinely unprecedented. Discover might try to pass the buck to its Collections department for any 'illegal ' activities, but it is its foundational policies that set up the damaging cycle leading to such harassment in the first place. 

Our daughter received two compensation letters from Discover, one on XX/XX/XXXX, and another on XX/XX/XXXX, seemingly propelled by CFPB 's scrutiny. However, this only occurred after she had defaulted, and the 'compensation ' was added back to her outstanding loan. My son also received a {$59.00} check from the CFPB on XX/XX/XXXX, for a related matter, along with four other letters from Discover acknowledging incorrect interest rate charges. 

Within our household, both of our XXXX children, despite being XXXX years apart in age, have fallen prey to these tactics. This experience illuminates the systemic targeting of vulnerable populations like ours and others struggling financially. 

Discover leverages this business model to infringe on the rights of borrowers, systematically inhibiting upward mobility for entire generations, including Millennials and XXXX XXXX, particularly those of XXXX. They gamble that few will have the courage or resources to oppose a financially robust institution backed by influential politicians. When similar outcomes manifest across millions of students, it's not the individual at faultit 's the predatory system they're ensnared in. 

Request from Discover Student Loans : Release the hold on our credits, and dismiss all litigations now that we have an agreed-upon and executed settlement. 

Included in the attachments : 1. Signed authorization letters 2. Civil Summons from Discover for all four file numbers 3. Settlement information 4. Arbitration documents 5. Requests for notarization documents sent by Discover/XXXX 6 . Notice from Discover of interest rate errors and applicable refunds ( does not account for high interest rates assigned upon inception of loans with high credit rating cosigners )

_source.complaint_what_happened:
Identity stolen and utilized to open a checking account with TD Bank. Received an email at XXXX on XX/XX/ thanking me for opening a XXXX XXXX account in my former legal name. I legally changed my name via court order in XX/XX/XXXX  prior to the identity theft. I called the TD Bank identity theft hotline, provided my SSN and name and other identifying information. 

Support could not provide me with the account number or any other information, but said I would be contacted via an investigator. Support was not able to verify whether or not they were closing the account immediately. Support was not able to offer a timeline for when the investigations team would contact me. After doing some research online, it appears that this situation is very common with TD Bank. 

Other consumers who have had this issue with TD Bank stated that TD Bank never conducted a thorough investigation into the identity theft, and never followed up. I was encouraged to submit this complaint in the hopes that TD Bank would follow through with my investigation.
_source.sub_issue: Account opened as a result of fraud

_source.complaint_what_happened:
In 2023, XXXX XXXX reduced my credit limit twice with no missed payments and minimum payments made. As a result, my credit score dropped significantly. In XXXX of 2023, I did a balance transfer to reduce the amount of the XXXX in half and pay more towards the balance to reduce the debt. Again, XXXX reduced my credit limit which again impacted my credit score. I called to ask why and sent a letter and was told verbally and via letter I could ask for a credit limit increase and stating to them this was an unfair practice of reducing the limit which impacts my credit utilization which in turn impacts my credit score. In XXXX of 2023, I requested a credit limit increase per the letter sent to me from XXXX and was denied the increase stating my monthly mortgage payment was not provided which I had updated in the app the prior month. Since then I have been working on paying the card completely off. 

Yesterday, I received a letter from Bank of America stating they have made the decision to reduce my credit line after reviewing my credit history, economic and loss trends and consumer reports. My XXXX XXXX is a direct reflection of the the credit limit decrease by XXXX and now Bank of America who have both impacted my utilization scoring. All of my accounts have been paid on time with more than the minimum and I have paid off two cards within the last 90 days totaling more than XXXX. 

If I am one person who has had this happen to them twice, just imagine the others who are in the same position being negatively impacted for utilizing credit and paying them off. My husband has had the same happen to him and has closed all of his credit accounts to avoid this and went into debt relief which should not have had to happen in paying a off the credit cards. This is unfair and malicious. If the end goal is to keep us all in debt just say that.
_source.sub_product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
_source.company_public_response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

_source.complaint_what_happened:
I have been attempting to assume my mortgage for a year following a divorce. I nearly completed the assumption process with my lender when my mortgage was sold to PNC. I started the assumption process with PNC the first week of XXXX, 2023. I did not receive a packet of information until the end of XXXX, and I have not submitted an official application for the loan yet. 

I was recently laid off, so I contacted PNC to understand my options. The representative told me that it would not get approved, and she recommended canceling the application for assumption to restart once I secure another job. She told me that the process would start back at square one, and I would have to pay the {$150.00} fee for application a second time. 

I asked if is was possible for me to get approved now, and she directly told me no, which I understand is something only the underwriters can determine. She also told me that because I reached out to PNC to inform them of my layoff, I essentially tied their hands. She mentioned that i just should have kept going with the process without informing PNC of the layoff- which I understand is considered mortgage fraud. I am concerned that the representative was alluding to this option in our conversation. 

The representative told me multiple times that she was new to the assumptions department, and when I asked to speak with someone else she said anyone would tell me the same thing. She attempted to get someone else on the line, but returned after 30 seconds saying everyone was busy. She told me she could " put an incomplete on it '' but that I would have to remind her to do it every 15 days. 

I can provide more information on my specific circumstances ; however, the timeline of this process is not acceptable, and the lack of support and consistent/ legal information from the representative at PNC is concerning.
_source.issue: Applying for a mortgage or refinancing an existing mortgage

_source.complaint_what_happened: On about XX/XX/XXXX I attempted a purchase however Bank of America had locked my card due to suspicious activity - a debit of approximately {$20.00}. When I called, I was told I would receive a replacement card. I activated the new card on XX/XX/XXXX but was unable to add the card to the Wallet on my XXXX. After nearly 2 hours on the phone with BofA ( during which I was asked to try various steps to add the card including removing all other cards from my XXXX Wallet ), I was told I was prevented from adding my card due to suspicious activity - the ~ {$20.00} debit the originated in Florida. The " manager '' informed me that it could take anywhere from a few days up to 6 to 9 months to be able to add the card to my phone or watch. The more I think about this situation, the more frustrated I get. I don't think I should be prevented from having easy access to my funds because of a {$20.00} suspicious transaction. Bank of America is treating me like I am criminal not like a XXXX  year-old who has had a banking relationship with B of A for decades and who has maintained relatively high balances with the bank. Hopefully you can help.

This reporting has severely damaged my financial situation. On XXXX, I noticed a new account on my credit report that I did not open. I immediately sent noticices to Discover Bank Financial Services, requesting them to validate the debt and remove it from my credit report. I sent this notice via certified mail with tracking number XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. Despite my notice, Discover Bank has not taken any action to remove the debt from my credit report. As a result, my credit score and report has been damaged, making it difficult for me to obtain credit, which I need to purchase a home. _source.complaint_what_happened:
At some point in XXXX 2022, my AA Advantage Aviator Red Mastercard account issued by Barclays had the address changed without my permission. Shortly thereafter, two charges for {$5000.00} each ( {$10000.00} total ) and then another for {$2100.00} were made in XXXX 2022. Those charges were paid directly from my XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX account. However, because the statements were not going to my house but instead to the address provided by the fraudster, I had no knowledge of the theft. 

At some point in XXXX 2022, Barclays issued a credit card with a different number under my legitimate account to a fraudulent authorized user. Under no circumstances did I request or provide information allowing an authorized user to be added. The fraudulent authorized user is XXXX XXXX and the address she is associated with is the same address my account was changed to in XXXX 2022. XXXX then attempted to add XXXX XXXX as another authorized user but was denied. I opened a formal complaint with Barclay in XXXX 2022 after I was denied a car loan due to delinquencies on my credit report, which were caused by XXXX 's theft. 

I spoke with Barclays multiple times inquiring about the investigation and the securities department at Barclays casually mentioned XXXX 's name stating she is a " known name '' to them. During the fraud at Barclays, XXXX also falsely acquired my XXXX card information and stole close to {$40000.00}. I have finally been reimbursed for those debits through XXXX but Barclays is not reimbursing me. It is important to note that XXXX also funneled monies to my credit cards from other banks, including XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. XXXX would make direct payments from these banks and then use the payments to make cash advances at XXXX XXXX in XXXX, Texas and XXXX XXXX in XXXX, Texas. XXXX has defrauded customers of each of these banks and used my Advantage Aviator Red Mastercard to funnel the funds to herself. I insisted Barclays give me all the information, including transcripts, indicating how XXXX was able to make herself an authorized user. Barclays nonchalantly indicated XXXX had my information and was approved as a user. Truly, the largest disservice besides the theft is that each time I speak to Barclays, I have to jump through hoops and security authorizations before Barclays will have a discussion with me yet a known fraudster was able to quite easily make themselves an authorized user. Barclays securities department is clearly lacking the ability to protect its customers. 

In XXXX 2022, Barclays sent a letter addressed to XXXX XXXX ( this was the first time XXXX was used but my statements as well as background checks have the name XXXX XXXX ) to my home address. The letter stated the primary account was closed due to suspicious activity and pending further investigation. This was the same account I reported to Barclays in XXXX 2022. Again, this is evidence of the incompetence within Barclays organization that they are now addressing a letter to me using the fraudster 's name. 

Barclays found fraudulent activity on my account and have not made any attempt to resolve the issue. Instead, I spend countless hours initiating conversations with them that are not helpful.

_source.complaint_what_happened: I spoke with Bank of America on XX/XX/year>, about a charge that appeared on my credit card of the amount of {$290.00}... I had Paid Off the balance approximately 4 or 5 days prior to the card 's due date, and had a XXXX XXXX showing for approximately 3 days on Bank of America 's website... I thought since I Paid the Balance that was Due in Full that I was done with payments and Free and Clear of this debt... When I checked my Bank of America on approximately the XXXX day after paying the account in Full, there was a charge for {$290.00}... I then called Bank of America to find out about this charge and was told it was an Interest Charge... I asked for what, because I had Paid Off the account in Full days prior to the Due Date, and I Paid the Exact Amount that it said I owed and couldn't understand why I had received this Interest Charge... I was told the new balance reflected Interest... I don't understand if I Paid the Full Amount in Full why I am being charged the {$290.00}... If this was correct, Bank of America should have listed in Plain Site the Full Payoff Amount... I feel that I am being Legally Robbed and Unfairly Billed since I Paid the Amount Due on the Bank of America website in Full... I believe that this is Deceptive Trickery on part of Bank of America.

_source.complaint_what_happened: A charge off account is showing on my report & the creditor told me that I can not get a copy of the 1099-C document because they did not officially charge off the debt and they didn't take a write off which is a violation because it says on my credit report that it is charged off which equates to false reporting & not reporting 100 % accurately. FCRA violations refers to a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, which is a federal law that regulates the collection, dissemination, and use of consumer credit information. Federal law requires that consumer reporting agencies follow reasonable procedures to ensure 100 % accuracy of the information contained in their credit reports. If a consumer suffers damages as a result of a FCRA violation they may be entitled to bring a private lawsuit against the CRA and recover actual damages, statutory damages, and attorney 's fees. These accounts listed on my letter are not 100 % correct and I demand them to be investigated completely.

_source.complaint_what_happened:
Hello- I'm a co-signer on my Son 's Student loan. In the recent past, i received an email from Discover Student loan department that my son was not paying up. I did remind my son to pay the outstanding which he did. The account has been normalized. 

I called in Discover on XX/XX/ to check the health status of the account and they did confirm that the account is in order. I logged into the student portal to gather more information about the loan such as an amortization statement as the he has about {$53000.00} in loan for a fixed term of 15 years. However, the Discover Student portal has no information whatsoever about the amortization statement relating the the forecast of the loan spread over 15 year period. There is no clear break up of interest versus principal. I spoke to two representatives today. The first rep put me on a long hold and disconnected the call. The second representative was more forthcoming and confirmed that there is no such statement such as amortization for student loan and he put me on hold. The second representative latter disconnected the call. 

I would request CFPB to hold the financial institutions to be responsible for not being transparent in the student loan arena. As such we have burgeoning student loans across the country. To top it financial institutions are not being transparent in their code. Enforcement of such rules and regulations will make student loan more transparent. 

Appreciate it. 

regards XXXX

_source.complaint_what_happened:
I made an insurance payment of {$130.00} for my auto insurance. Everything appeared okay with this until I received an email from Bank of America stating that on XX/XX/XXXX I did not have enough money in my account ending in XXXX to cover my transaction. The following is a copy and paste exactly as the email read. 

Your account may have insufficient funds On XX/XX/2023, you didn't have enough money in your XXXX XXXX XXXX account ending in XXXX to cover your transaction ( s ). 
Balance after transaction ( s ) and fees : {$180.00} Transaction type ELECTRONIC PAYMENT Amount {$130.00} Transaction paid? No Fee {$0.00} Check your balance. If it's negative, make a deposit right away to bring it above {$0.00} and have enough money to cover upcoming transactions. 

There was {$180.00} in my account and the payment was for {$130.00}. This makes no sense to me but as I was logged into my Bank of America account and speaking to the rep over the phone telling her the payment had NOT been returned I watched the screen change and suddenly the check showed up as returned. I have no clue why they did this but the rep tried to explain that the posting I was seeing was not the way it really was. It was some other way and she tried to tell me where I could go in my account to see the way my transactions REALLY posted. I have no clue what she is talking about but the view I was looking at is the same one I have always relied on to check my bank account. I am sending you a copy of the email they sent me and a copy of my bank statement exactly like it is online. I do not see a problem at all with the way I did things and was not charged a fee. I'm sure I know why now. I just want to make you aware that Bank of America is doing something that is not right here and I would like you to look into it for me. They have been in trouble before for rearranging transactions to generate overdrafts and this is similar to that type of business. If this is what they are doing I do not want to do business with them any longer. Please look into this for me. Thank you

_source.complaint_what_happened:
This case is opened as " XXXX XXXX ''. I am still in Discovers system under my maiden name " XXXX XXXX ''. 

In XXXX of XXXX auto-pay was turned off on my Discover card account. I relied on this function to prevent late payments. I did not turn off this function. 

In XXXX of XXXX my husband was looking through our financial information and discovered my XXXX XXXX was XXXX points lower than it should be. Upon further investigation we discovered that I had several late payments on my Discover card. I was confused since I had auto-pay enabled. 

We contacted Discover via chat where a representative confirmed there were late payments and that auto-pay had been XXXX in XX/XX/XXXX. We were very confused and asked them to investigate how this happened. The rep said auto-pay had been " turned off by our system '' but also said they did not see any notifications sent out that would be consistent with their system disabling auto-pay. They said they actually were seeing that it was XXXX on " web/online ''. The discover rep said that they would be able to refund the late fees and have it removed from our account. They said to wait until this posted in XXXX hours then contact the credit bureaus to get the late payments removed from my credit. 

Upon further investigation on the CFPB website I found that it is actually the responsibility of Discover to contact the credit bureaus to fix this and not my responsibility as a consumer. 

I contacted Discover to have them work directly with the credit bureaus. I was transferred to supervisors who said that even though I did not cancel auto-pay, they could not find an error on their side and therefore were not able to contact the credit bureaus to get these late payments removed. They stated they could only do this if they found that they had made a mistake. 

I have several issues with this : 1. There is no 3rd party verification of their findings that there was no bug or IT error that could have caused an auto-pay disable. As I said, I did not disable auto-pay for exactly this reason.

2. Banks never admit culpability so if the only way they would report this to the credit bureau is if they were culpable... they never clean up anything they get wrong? 
XXXX. This is an incentive for banks to purposefully cancel auto-pay on their consumers to get late fees from them. Then if consumers catch them they just give the money back and deny culpability because there is no third party investigation. 

This is theft from the consumer ( in this case me ) and to their credit they returned the late fee money. However I still have negative marks on my credit report and Discover is claiming there is no way to help me get these removed. 

I am seeking CFPB assistance in getting Discover to work with the credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, XXXX ) to remove the derogatory remarks from my credit report.

_source.complaint_what_happened: In XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX, a debt collection agency contacted me multiple times within a XXXX period, making four calls and leaving two voicemails. Additionally, they contacted my sister and mother without my consent, attempting to use them to reach me. These actions were distressing and felt harassing. I have been registered on the National Do Not Call list since XX/XX/XXXX. The debt collector 's conduct appears to violate the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), the Telephone Consumer Protection Act ( TCPA ), and potentially other consumer protection laws, given the unsolicited calls. Despite not initiating any direct contact with the debt collector, their aggressive attempts have caused significant emotional distress. I have retained call records, voicemails, and messages from my sister and mother as evidence of these incidents.

_source.complaint_what_happened:
I am writing to file a formal complaint regarding a violation of FDIC rules and federal law by USAA. Upon reviewing my recent account activity, I discovered an unauthorized overdraft charge applied to my account. It has come to my attention that USAA has charged me an overdraft fee, despite my explicit lack of consent for overdraft protection services. 

I would like to clarify that at no point did I sign up for overdraft protection, nor did I authorize any overdraft transactions to be approved by USAA. This action is in direct violation of federal law, as I never opted-in or agreed upfront that the bank could charge me an overdraft fee or approve any transaction that overdraws my account. 

Furthermore, USAA claims to have provided a letter automatically enrolling me in overdraft protection, which I never approved. This misleading action is not only unauthorized but also mischievous, violating my rights as a consumer and undermining the trust I place in financial institutions.
_source.issue: Problem caused by your funds being low

_source.complaint_what_happened: I have filed a dispute with XXXX and PNC Bank in regards to consultation services never received by a company called XXXX XXXX in the amount of {$160.00} for a transaction that ocurred on XX/XX/2023. I sent XXXX copies of the email showing that I paid for a service. I also included a note via XXXX with the purpose of my payment. I disputed the transaction after not receiving service. I have tried to reach out to the Seller via email but received no response. XXXX has failed to provide the XXXX XXXX as promised for transactions that take place on their platform.. I appealed their decision and still have not received funds. I reached out to my bank PNC in regards to this matter and received no assistance. I am willing to go to my local police dept and contact my attorney regarding this matter. As a customer, I am very disappointed that XXXX and my bank-PNC has failed to protect my money. _source.product: Payday loan, title loan, personal loan, or advance loan
_source.complaint_what_happened:
I took out a personal loan with XXXX by Goldman Sachs in XXXX of XXXX. I was current on all payments when the loan was suddenly sold to XXXX and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX in XXXX of XXXX. After the sale and subsequent consumer notice, I was unable to access any information on my loan from the XXXX XXXX XXXX and had to work through XXXX for all account statements, payment, and payoff information. 

Upon notice of this, I paid off the loan, at XXXX, immediately. My balance was {$0.00} at the end of XXXX, and no statements were generated. 

As of XX/XX/XXXX, I noticed that the XXXX account XXXX still displayed as 'open ' in my report with all three credit report bureaus. I filed disputes with all three indicating the account was sold, and that it should be showing closed. In all cases, XXXX XXXX XXXX to the credit bureaus showing the account should remain open with the same balance as when the loan was sold. There have been no subsequent payments or late assessments to the account- it has just stayed stagnant on my profile. 

In certain cases, a similar account was opened with XXXX in XXXX of XXXX on my credit profile, showing the amount of the loan balance at sale. Some of those have subsequently closed. This indicates that the loan did indeed transfer entities, and XXXX XXXX not file the appropriate paperwork with the credit bureaus to show the closures when they offboarded the loans. And further, upon inquiry from the credit reporting agencies, they again confirmed that they believe the account should reflect as 'open '.

This complaint is a followup of my prior complaint ; XXXX, which was not resolved to my satisfaction. 

I am writing in response to PNCs letter dated XX/XX/XXXX, regarding my complaint filed on XX/XX/XXXX, concerning the assumption of my mortgage loan. I appreciate PNCs detailed response and their efforts to address my concerns. However, there are several discrepancies and additional points that need clarification and resolution. 

Timeline and Communication Issues In PNCs response, it was stated that the Initial Assumption Request Form was received on XX/XX/XXXX. However, I submitted the initial assumption application form on XX/XX/XXXX. I realized I had forgotten to attach the divorce decree and followed up on XX/XX/XXXX, to correct this oversight. I followed up again on XX/XX/XXXX, as I had not received any response to my communications sent in XXXX. I have the email thread to support this timeline. 


Request to Pause the Process My request to PNC was to pause the assumption process due to my layoff. I specifically asked for this to prevent further complications. Despite this request, the following occurred : On XX/XX/XXXX, PNC sent a Notice of Incomplete Application, requesting I unfreeze my XXXX credit report, sign and date the previously provided Intent To Proceed, and return the document by XX/XX/XXXX. 
On XX/XX/XXXX, the assumption application was closed for incompleteness because the requested documentation was not received. 
On XX/XX/XXXX, a new Initial Assumption Request Form was emailed to me. 
I was advised by XXXX over the phone not to take any action on this matter, as she was actively trying to help pause the assumption process. This advice directly conflicts with the subsequent actions taken by PNC, leading to further delays and confusion. 


Concerns About Representatives Advice and Communication In my initial complaint, I expressed concerns that a PNC representative suggested I should not have informed PNC about my layoff, which is misleading and potentially suggests mortgage fraud. While I appreciate that PNC has escalated this concern to the appropriate management level, I would like to be informed of the outcome of this investigation to ensure that such advice is not given to other customers in the future. 

Additionally, XXXX never responded to any emails I sent her. She only followed up with me over the phone, calling at her convenience, allowing significant time to pass before following up with me.. I realize now that this was to avoid any sort of paper trail, as she made a lot of promises and statements to follow up with items during our phone conversations that I never heard back about. This included her commitment to putting a pause on the assumption and determining a way to avoid needing additional signatures from my abusive ex-husband. It was for my self-preservation that I specifically did not want him included in the process. 


Current Status and Emotional Impact I now have a new job and an offer letter, but I was not told what to do next, other than to complete the Initial Assumption Request Form that was sent to me four days ago, which is the exact same form I filled out and sent in XX/XX/XXXX. This form requires more signatures from my abusive ex-husband, which I had hoped to avoid. XXXX sympathized with this and understood the dynamic, and told me she would help me avoid needing his signatures in any way possible. It feels like I spent the last two months fighting for something that ultimately got me nowhere. If I hadnt made the original complaint in XXXX, I believe I would be in the same position I am today or possibly further down the process. It took months of effort, fighting, and phone calls for what seems to be no progress. 


Issues Not Fully Addressed - Competence of the Representative and Availability of Others : The response did not address the competence of the new representative or the difficulty I experienced in speaking with other representatives when I needed assistance. 
- Confusion Internally About the Process, Needs, and Timelines. 
- Application Fee : The response did not address the additional {$150.00} fee required to restart the assumption process, which I find unreasonable given the circumstances. 


Comparison with XXXX Before my mortgage was sold to PNC on XX/XX/XXXX, I nearly completed the assumption process with XXXX. This process was significantly shorter and less expensive. I was less than two weeks away from finalizing everything when the loan was transferred to PNC. There was no understanding or assistance provided during this transition, aside from instructions on where to pay my bills. The lack of support and continuity during this transition period has been very challenging. XXXX only required a {$25.00} fee to run a credit check and only required my ex-husbands signature on the final closing paperwork. Additionally, I was told that their process overall would take approximately six weeks, which is much shorter than the six-plus months PNC has stated. I am very confused why the same process varies so significantly between companies. 


Proposed Resolutions Given the above points, I request the following resolutions : - Clarification and Correction of the Timeline : Acknowledge the actual dates of my communications and submission of the initial assumption application form. Provide an accurate timeline for the remainder of the assumption process from now until close. 
- Pause the Assumption Process Without Penalty : Honor my initial request to pause the assumption process without requiring me to restart and incur additional fees. 
Allow me to send in updated information, including new job details and verification paperwork, as well as updated bank and credit card statements. This will be added to the already existing packet of paperwork I completed and returned to PNC on XX/XX/XXXX, and will continue with the assumption process from where I left off in XX/XX/XXXX. 
This includes using the already signed request to assume a mortgage, the already completed assumption packet, the already paid application fee, and the previously requested credit report. 
If it is mandatory to start the process over, then I request the additional application fee of {$150.00} be waived. To maintain my safety, I also request that PNC contact my abusive ex-husband for signatures. 
- Improved Communication and Support : Ensure that I receive clear and consistent information from knowledgeable representatives throughout the remainder of this process. I want to have an advocate for my best interests rather than someone who prioritizes the interests of PNC. 
- Outcome of Investigation : Inform me of the outcome of the investigation regarding the misleading advice given by the representative. 

I appreciate your attention to this matter.

_source.sub_issue: Trying to communicate with the company to fix an issue with the application process

_source.complaint_what_happened:
On XX/XX/year> my computer and accounts were hacked and I tried to resolve the issue with USAA over fraudulent charges. Initially they were great the charges in question were reversed. There were charges at multiple stores within the mall : XXXX for XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX totaling XXXX. Then the card was attempted to be used at the XXXX XXXX  for XXXX and then XXXX both of which were declined ( and have since disappeared from my pending charges ). As this was occuring I received a text from USAA about fraudulent charges that had multiple line items and I recognized several ( including a payment I had made earlier in the day ) I didn't notice the XXXX charge which was the first one listed. Once I contacted them regarding the charges hours after the event I stated that I responded Y to recognizing the charges but had not seen the first line item on the text and that was fraud but the others were not. I went through every charge I had made and verified all charges except the XXXX in even increments. They shut down that card and sent me a new one overnight. 
Next I contacted all three credit bureaus to put fraud alerts and a credit freeze for my ssn. The freeze and fraud alerts are still in place to this day. 
I continued on using the card as I normally do until the XXXX in XXXX  charges were put back on my account on XXXX. I received letters stating that they were not fraud ( despite them recognizing and declining similar charges and amounts within minutes of the XXXX  ones for fraud suspicion ). I contacted them back on XXXX after receiving this letter, restated my frustration and was told a supervisor would look into it and reach back out in 3-5 business days. I have heard nothing from them and am not getting any resolution even when I am told it is being looked into, nor did I ever receive any information regarding why they determined there was no fraudulent activity. I have a 20 year banking history with USAA for checking, savings, and insurance although the credit card was opened this year and am disappointed that I can not get any resolution and they are not upholding the fraud liability as originally stated.

_source.complaint_what_happened:
This dispute is regarding a fraudulent purchase on our company credit card discovered in XXXX. There was an inadequate investigation by Bank of America and they have denied crediting our account. Bank of America Case # XXXX We are a small general contractor with a newer account at Bank of America and are a premiere customer. I am a former employee of the company and have had accounts with them for over 20 years. This has put an immense burden on a small business. 

We review our card statements constantly which is done by my finance leader. She discovered a questionable {$8500.00} purchase which had occurred in XX/XX/2022 and I believed she had flagged it with the bank. I discovered in XXXX as the charge was still showing that there was a problem and reported it to the bank XXXX line I received a letter on XX/XX/XXXX attached stating denial for " inconsistent details surrounding the claim '' ( letter attached ). I was very surprised as it is very clearly not our purchase. 

I called XX/XX/XXXX to the XXXX line and asked what to do. The bank responded that we could appeal this decision and asked for additional information. They did not clarify what information was inconsistent and told me to write a letter to a XXXX XXXX XXXX I asked to be able to email a manager or an actual person and was told only a letter could be sent. The agent indicated to me that we could be part of a scheme which I found offensive. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I asked our local branch manager for help and she asked me to provide a copy of the letter I sent to the XXXX XXXX and the regional manager would call me. It's been six weeks with no response. 

I then conducted my own investigation with the merchant and discovered multiple problems. The merchant is XXXX XXXX XXXX of XXXX XXXX NY - an electrical and microwave component supplier. This is what I learned : The vendors authorization form is attached 1. Somehow the fraudster had our card number but : : 2. The given name ( XXXX XXXX ) is not the cardholder or anyone associated with our company 3. The company name collected " Synergy '' is not our company name 4. The contacts ; phone/email collected for XXXX XXXX are not accurate and I called and emailed this person 4x to try to sort it out but they are dead contacts 5. The components ( XXXX XXXX  ) are not something a dock builder purchases and should have been flagged immediately by the banks fraud toolset. 
6. The shipping address was listed as " XXXX XXXX '' I was able to track down and discover that the materials were shipped XXXX XXXX I had notified the vendor to publish a chargeback but they said it had to be done by the bank. 

Since this time I have called the XXXX line 4-5 times for a follow-up. I have visited my branch 4x inquiring about the escalation. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, the branch manager informed me verbally that I have been sent a letter indicating that we reported the issue too late and that the case would be closed. I have received no letter to that effect and despite many attempts to resolve heard this for the first time yesterday. 

Despite multiple attempts to escalate, speak to anyone in authority - I can't resolve what is clearly a fraud issue. I spoke to XXXX XXXX people and no one could tell me if the claim had even been reviewed or the documentation I provided had been investigated. I did a lot of research for the bank that should have cleared our account. 

I have no choice and have to file this CFPB complaint and will be grateful for your assistance. I have filed a report with the FBI and will be contacting the Attorney General 's offices in New York and North Carolina.

_source.complaint_what_happened:
Subject : FORMAL DISPUTE AND DEMAND FOR IMMEDIATE REMOVAL OF INACCURATE INFORMATION AND DEBT VALIDATION Account : APPLE CARD - GS BANK Account Numbers : XXXX Notice to Agent is Notice to Principle and Notice to Principle is Notice to Agent, I am writing to demand the immediate removal of inaccurate and conflicting information on my credit file for the accounts listed above. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), you are legally required to report only accurate and verifiable information. Failure to comply with FCRA Section 611 mandates the removal or correction of inaccurate information within 30 days. 

Due to the recent XXXX XX/XX/XXXX data breach, which exposed sensitive consumer data, it is imperative that my information be handled with utmost care to mitigate risks of identity theft and fraud. 

Discrepancies in Reporting : The APPLE CARD - GS BANK account, under account number XXXX, exhibits significant inconsistencies : 1. Conflicting Status Update Dates : One report lists a charge-off status update in XX/XX/XXXX, while another lists it in XX/XX/XXXX. 
2. Payment History Mismatch : Inconsistencies in the payment history for charge-offs and delinquency periods between the two accounts.

3. Missing Original Creditor Information : Goldman Sachs is listed as the original creditor in one report but omitted in another.

4. Unverified Highest Balance Information : One report states the highest balance as {$1900.00}, while the other omits this information. 

This conflicting information is unverifiable and does not accurately reflect my credit activity. Under FCRA Section 611, I demand the immediate removal of this account from my credit report.

Demand for Debt Validation : Under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), I request full validation of this debt. You are required to provide : 1. Proof the debt belongs to me.

2. A full accounting of the balance, including how {$1800.00} was calculated.

3. Copies of the original signed agreement indicating my legal obligation to pay this debt.

4. Name and contact information of the original creditor, along with all related documentation. 

If this debt can not be fully validated within 30 days, you must remove it from my credit report and cease all reporting. Non-compliance will be considered a willful violation of FCRA Section 611 and FDCPA, prompting me to pursue all available legal remedies, including filing complaints with the CFPB and considering a lawsuit under federal law.

Expectations for Resolution : An immediate investigation into this account is mandatory. Provide verifiable proof that this debt is mine and accurate, or remove this item from my credit report.

Failure to resolve this matter within 30 days will result in : 1. Filing formal complaints with the CFPB and FTC.

2. Considering legal action for damages due to willful non-compliance under the FCRA, entitling me to statutory damages and compensation for harm caused by incorrect reporting. 

Given the data breach, the urgency of this matter can not be overstated. Notify me in writing of the investigation results and provide an updated copy of my credit report once changes are made. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this serious matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX [ Agent/Beneficiary ] without prejudice, all natural inalienable rights reserved.
_source.issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem

_source.complaint_what_happened:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, NC XXXX Email Address : XXXX Phone : XXXX Date : XX/XX/XXXX Dear Financial Consumer Complaint Department I am writing to file a financial consumer complaint against Busey Bank regarding the handling of my account closure request of : Checking Account : [ Account Number Ending in XXXX ] Savings Account : [ Account Number Ending in XXXX ] I sent a formal closure letter via registered mail to Busey Bank of XXXX Illinois on XX/XX/XXXX, addressed to XXXX XXXX, requesting the closure of my checking and savings accounts due to a significant life change, specifically, my relocation to XXXX, North Carolina. In the following weeks, I followed up with XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and a few others. Who always tell me a banker will cal. I have no missed calls from Busey. On XX/XX/XXXX. I spoke to XXXX, who transferred me to XXXX, who essentially asked the same verifications questions. 

Despite multiple attempts to resolve this matter, I have encountered significant obstacles and delays. To date, I have spoken with over XXXX supervisors at Busey Bank, all of whom have promised that a banker would contact me, but to no avail. Additionally, I have been subjected to repetitive questioning regarding my signature, which has been impacted by a XXXX, resulting in XXXX XXXX XXXX 

Furthermore, Busey Bank has refused to accept a letter from my XXXX XXXX doctor, verifying my identity in person. This refusal has hindered the closure process and prevented me from accessing my funds, which are urgently needed to secure housing in my new location. 

In contrast, I have successfully opened a checking and savings account with XXXX XXXX Bank XXXX XXXX in XXXX, where Banker XXXX XXXX attempted to facilitate a wire transfer of my funds from Busey Bank. However, this transfer was inexplicably refused by Busey Bank, further exacerbating my situation. 

I am deeply distressed by the lack of responsiveness and cooperation from Busey Bank, especially considering my current displaced status and urgent need for access to my funds. I believe that Busey Bank 's actions, including their refusal to accept valid documentation and their failure to facilitate the closure process, constitute a violation of consumer rights and banking regulations. 

Therefore, I respectfully request that the Financial Consumer Complaint Department investigate this matter promptly and take appropriate action to ensure that Busey Bank complies with all relevant regulations and resolves this issue satisfactorily. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. Should you require any further information or assistance, please do not hesitate to contact me at XXXX or XXXX. 

Yours sincerely, XXXX XXXX

I am writing to formally report an issue with National Credit Systems ( NCS ) regarding inaccurate reporting of debts on my credit report. Despite multiple attempts to resolve these discrepancies directly with NCS and through the major credit bureaus, I have been unsuccessful in obtaining verification or resolution.

I discovered several debts listed on my credit report from NCS that do not belong to me and were inaccurately attributed to my credit history. These debts were reported by NCS without any validation or proof that I am responsible for them. I promptly submitted disputes through XXXX XXXX and directly to the three major credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX ), requesting verification of these debts and removal if unable to provide sufficient proof. 

The original creditor and account numbers are unknown, but the open balances are {$17000.00} ( opened XX/XX/XXXX ) and {$11000.00} ( opened XX/XX/XXXX ). 

In my communications with NCS, I have explicitly stated that I do not recognize these debts and have requested validation documents, including proof of my signature agreeing to these debts. Despite my requests, NCS has failed to provide any documentation verifying these debts as mine or proving that I am legally obligated to pay them. Furthermore, NCS has repeatedly refused to remove these inaccurate entries from my credit report, which has severely impacted my creditworthiness and financial standing.

Enclosed with this complaint are copies of all relevant documentation, including my credit report highlighting the disputed items and records of communication with NCS and the credit bureaus.

I am seeking the assistance of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) to investigate this matter thoroughly and ensure that National Credit Systems complies with federal regulations concerning fair and accurate credit reporting. 1. This is not an authorized charge. I have never made a purchase with XXXX. Multiple charges of varying amounts were attempted by XXXX on XXXX, all of which were disputed when called in.
